title: Wednesday, 4th April, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:06 am

Sorry -- lots of dead air today. Internet's being a bit tricky.

...... Clearly, clearly we cannot and will not speculate about WPP.

WPP PLC (WPP:LSE): Last: 1,101, down 17 (-1.52%), High: 1,111, Low: 1,074, Volume: 2.64m

We can merely state the facts. WPP is investigating Sorrell over an allegation of personal misconduct.

BE11:27am

Miss Piggy @BE: alleged by whom?

misuse of assets and improper personal behavior, it is alleged.

"The allegations do not involve amounts which are material to WPP," says WPP, which is interesting I guess.

Soundbuy @ Forester - anywhere south of the Wash is fine, bar Wales, soya breeders in Ukraine, Russia etc have bred varieties (non-GM) well suited to our latitudes.....

The idea for a while is that WPP's not really fit for purpose any more so would be better broken up.

Miss Piggy TV

Seems a prime candidate.

BE11:35am

Anyway, stick with the main FT coverage, where things are lawyered before publication. We don't have that luxury here so should probably move on.

Morrison mentioned.

WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 217.20, up 4.9 (+2.31%), High: 217.70, Low: 212.60, Volume: 6.16m
BornCynic Te he - "misuse of assets and personal wrogdoing" - reminds me of a senior Pfizer exec having "physiotherapy" in one of the New York flats. He was just told not to use company property...........
11:36 am
BE11:36am

Leading the big-four in March, Kantar says.

Miss Piggy "WPP trading less than sum of its parts" Brian Wieser
BE11:36am

4.6% or thereabouts by till roll in a market doing 1.1% overall.

BE11:37am

Asda also very strong, notably, with the discounters a wee bit weaker than usual.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

We've also got Macquarie pushing Morrison on an argument that's very similar to the one put forward by Bernstein last week.

BE11:39am

We raise MRW to OP (from N); we are buyers here as the business and the
shares are at an inflection point. It has significant opportunities to grow and
create value despite being the smallest of the Big 4. We highlight three reasons
to buy now: #1) Wholesale is a significant but underappreciated opportunity; #2)
Core Retail is in good shape with self-help potential; #3) Strong cash flow and an
increasingly capital-light model helps MRW return c20% of market cap over next
three years.

BE11:39am

The wholesale stuff in there's probably the most interesting bit, particularly in light of Tesco-Booker and Conviviality's failure.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Our deep dive into the £30bn Wholesale sector and margin structure of the 11
privately held operators highlights a fragmented industry in distress; creating a
significant opportunity for MRW. Its buying scale at 5x its nearest competitor and
vertical integration – analysis of its six processing subsidiaries points to c30% of
internally sourced COGS – are clear competitive advantages. McColls’ focus on
the growing the Convenience market and aggressive plans to raise
Grocery/Fresh sales make it an ideal partner. MRW can leverage this with the
Safeway brand to build a meaningful position in this market: a 10% share
creates a £3bn revenue opportunity with c£100mn profit; we now incorporate
£1.1bn/£27mn in wholesale revenue/profit in FY20/21. This greater scale should
also help Retail margins; we raise our three-year target to 3.0% (from 2.7%).

BE11:40am

That's the gist of that.

chad_john Speaking of Conviviality, any update on that?
Mouselet Someone deciding to protest against YouTube's opaque moderation techniques with a handgun was a bit unfortunate
BE11:40am

While on broker stuff, should mention miners ....

11:41 am
BE11:41am

RBC pushing Glencore, which also had a bit of a run yesterday afternoon ...

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 347.05, down 9.2 (-2.58%), High: 359.50, Low: 346.10, Volume: 16.51m
BE11:42am

.... though is back with the sector now. Theme is sell iron ore for the short term, but stick with the survivors as balance sheets are fine now.

Swedish Chef @Mouse All YouTube employees ought to be (heavily) armed so that they can return fire. Stands to reason dunnit?
rw42 Be interesting to see some stuff on cost of bitcoin mining compared to coin value now that it's on a downwards trajectory - sooner or later it just won't be effective to mine for any more, and at that point everything stops..
Forester @chad_john looks like InBev are going to use Matthew Clark to foister terrible Budveiser onto punters via the back door!
11:42 am

Suggestions going round a of another party interested. Not ADM or Glencore, a third party.

#REF! Budveiser really shows the power of advertising imo, given it's relative success over here and "flavour profile"
Mouselet it's only spirits that are effective per anum
BE11:44am

That's very much a market rumour though, to be clear. We've no clarity.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Anyway, here's what RBC makes of the sector.

Mouselet No, because Youtube took down the videos, because Americans apparently don't believe in sub judice and the preservation of evidence
BE11:44am

(@Grouchmonkey: no.)

BE11:45am

We continue to see the European metals and mining space in good health. Financial leverage is no longer an issue in our view, even if there was to be a period of sharply lower prices (which we think in the near-term is possible). In general, portfolios have been upgraded and we beleive free cash yields provide ample flexibility. At 5.0x EV/EBITDA, valuations remain inexpensive vs. fair value 6.5x long-term.

The imposition of global tariffs (see "Tarrif-iying, for now") combined with a cyclically slowing China, could cause further weakness in key commodities in the near-term in our view. Iron ore, for instance, appears to be at risk with steel inventories and property demand signals especially weak. Should Chinese steel margins fall from their current elevated levels, we see the potential for iron ore to fall in the near-term. This negative price momentum is likely to see companies like Rio Tinto and Vale underperform in the near-term owing to their high iron ore exposure. Heading out of this destocking period, however, we continue to expect higher iron ore prices than consensus and would look to any commodity driven de-rating as a buying opportunity.

11:45 am
BE11:46am

We increase our recommendation on Glencore to Top Pick, PT460p (previously Outperform, PT470p) as it does not have iron ore exposure, its valuation has retraced and we see cobalt, thermal coal and copper as less likely to be impacted by tariff/risk off pressures. We upgrade BHP to Sector Perform, PT1,400p (previously Underperform, PT 1,450p) with shares trading at our fair value estimates and potentially positive upcoming catalysts. Our target price for Anglo American (Outperform, 1,950p from 2,200p) falls, but we continue to view the investment case favourably. We see Rio Tinto (Sector Perform, 3,900p from 4,200p) facing the most challenges in this coming environment, and it holds a premium valuation; however, fundamentally we continue to see medium-term upside.

Swedish Chef Budvar v Budweiser. Providing work for lawyers since 1906. The Czechs have the better beer, the Yanks the better lawyers.
Forester @#Ref mind you their new Bud Lite "dilly dilly" ads are an epic fail of misunderstanding the differences this side of the pond!
BE11:46am

And on the precious ....

BE11:46am

We also upgrade Polymetal (Outperform, 910p from Sector Perform, 900p), Fresnillo (Sector Perform, 1,200p from Underperform), Gold Fields (Sector Perform, ZAR43 from Underperform, ZAR44), largely on valuations following a de-rating in the gold space. We downgrade Randgold (Underperform, 4,900p from Sector Perform, 6,200p) as we do not see the company being able to maintain its current multiple in a more challenging environment. We also downgrade Petra Diamonds (Sector Perform, 80p from Outperform, 85p), where we continue to see long-term upside (and rising diamond prices); however highlight the stronger rand forecasts reduce the near-term risk/reward outlook. ...

undefined

Nothing through yet on Conviviality / C&C, sorry.

11:49 am

BE11:51am

Anyway, Matthew Clark seems an obvious fit for C&C, which tries to buy nearly everything and has failed so far to make any kind of progress in the wholesale markets.

BE11:52am

Inbev support also key. I can come back to it if we get anything more.

FATDAZ @forester miss selling surely

Grouchmonkey OnTheMarket apparently still alive
11:56 am
BE11:56am

Oh, Fidessa! Of course.

BE11:56am

Somewhat late in the process, two more bidders turn up.

FATDAZ @BE new broom in at the top at Mothercare ? from KMart though US press was full of stories of KMARTs impending demise yday so ay be frying pan to fire for all
BE11:58am

Shares already trading well through, suggesting we're hoping for a bump from Temenos ..... Which ...... well, maybe.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Here's UBS.

BE11:58am

We currently estimate 14%
accretion in 2019 and 18% in 2020, assuming the full $60m in cost synergies are
realised by then. In order to keep to its ceiling of a 4x EBITDA leverage ratio, we
estimate Temenos will need to issue $600m of equity under the terms of its current
offer. If Temenos matched the mooted £38.297 offer of the third party, it would need
to add another $100m to its equity raise, we calculate. However, we note that
Temenos CEO David Arnott was quoted by Reuters as saying "We have made a fair
offer" at the time the offer was first announced, meaning a higher offer from Temenos
may not be forthcoming.

BE11:59am

And Kepler.

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

While no details were given on
the third parties, both private equity funds (given the recurrence of Fidessa
revenues) or a US competitor could be interested, in our view.

BE12:01pm

Advent? Sungard? Markit? Maybe even Bloomberg? Or the PE firm that recently sold that trade thing to Nordic Capital? We don't know.

BE12:01pm

HGCapital. That's the name I was looking for,

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

But, as I say, total speculation. We don't know.

BE12:02pm

Back to Kepler.

BE12:02pm

Raising the offer by 5% would mean another USD100m to be financed either
in additional debt or equity. This would not significantly change the accretive
impact of the deal (14% accretive instead of 15% if financed with more
equity, negligible if finance in additional debt) nor the expected return on
capital employed; the price offered represents 24x Fidessa EBIT, but with
the synergies expected, Fidessa margins could nearly double and then the
price offered was ultimately only slightly over 10x EBITA, becoming much
more reasonable. We hope management will have enough financial
discipline and not go for a valuation 15-20% higher if another offer comes.

BornCynic Thanks BE for another solo effort.
Grouchmonkey Txbye
12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

And Citi, since it's on my screen.

BE12:03pm

We think that Temenos is unlikely to be drawn into a
bidding war for Fidessa for at least three reasons. (1) At the recent CMD, Temenos’
CEO stated that he would only do deals “with strong industrial logic” and that are
“strongly accretive.” Based on its investments, which have led to increasing
profitability as well as share buybacks, we believe that Temenos management has
been a good steward of shareholder capital in recent years and believe that it will
continue to be. Our rough M&A math suggests that if Temenos were to increase its
offer by 5%, the deal would be 9% accretive to our pro forma 2019 EPS estimate,
assuming no revenue synergies and no margin improvement. (2) Our recent travels
with Temenos reinforced the view that management will remain disciplined with
shareholder capital (see note). (3) Temenos, in our view, does not need this asset.
An acquisition of Fidessa would allow Temenos to expand into capital markets
software, a market in which it currently does not operate. As such, we view a
potential acquisition of Fidessa as opportunistic and not borne out of strategic
necessity. Moreover, should another entity acquire Fidessa, we believe that it would
in no way disadvantage Temenos in the core banking software market.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Okay, that'll do for Wednesday. Thanks for joining.

Miss Piggy cheers

BE12:06pm

Back tomorrow, which'll be just as slow and lumpy as today. Apologies in advance, and afternoon all.
